content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Cynthia Williams: I was born and raised in Columbia, South Carolina, in a tight-knit neighborhood where everyone knew each other. My parents worked hard to provide for our family, and though we didn't have a lot of money, we always made do. I grew up with my two younger siblings, and we were close-knit. My father worked at a local factory, and my mother was a part-time clerk at a grocery store. Both of them only made it through high school, but they always encouraged me and my siblings to keep learning. I was a pretty quiet kid, always more interested in books and music than in sports or parties. I had a few friends, but I was more of an introvert. I remember walking to school every day with my backpack on my shoulder, listening to my headphones and dreaming about what I wanted to be when I grew up. I didn't have a lot of money, but I had a lot of love and support from my family. I graduated high school and started working part-time at a local bookstore to help out with expenses. I'm still figuring out what I want to do with my life, but I know I want to make something of myself, no matter how long it takes.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Cynthia Williams: There was a moment like that, actually. It happened right after I graduated high school. I had a few options in front of me, but none of them felt quite right. I could have gone to community college, but I wasn't sure if I wanted to commit to that yet. I could have taken a job full-time at the bookstore where I was working part-time, but I felt like I was just putting off the future. And then there was the option of taking a gap year, traveling, or doing something else to figure myself out. I remember sitting on my bedroom floor, surrounded by old notebooks and college brochures, feeling completely lost. I didn't know if I wanted to be a teacher, a writer, or even something else entirely. My parents didn't push me in any particular direction, but they did tell me, 'Whatever you choose, just don't stop learning.' That stuck with me. In the end, I decided to take a gap year, not to travel, but to work part-time and save up for community college. That decision taught me a lot about responsibility and patience. It also gave me time to reflect on what I truly wanted. I still don't have all the answers, but I feel like I'm on the right path now.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Cynthia Williams: I think it was a mix of both, honestly. I didn't just fall into a decision, but I also didn't force myself into one either. It felt like the right time to take a step back and not rush into something just because I thought I should. I remember talking to my mom one night, and she said something like, 'You don't have to have everything figured out right now. Just keep moving forward, even if it's one step at a time.' That really stuck with me. I didn't make a grand, dramatic choice, but I made a choice that felt responsible and thoughtful. I think that's what makes it real — not a sudden epiphany, but a quiet moment of clarity that builds over time.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Cynthia Williams: Absolutely. I think if I had talked to someone who could help me see things from a different perspective, it might have made the decision easier. I remember thinking about talking to a counselor at the community center, but I was too shy to ask for help. I didn't want to bother anyone or seem like I wasn't capable of figuring things out on my own. But in hindsight, I think having someone to bounce ideas off of — even just for a few minutes — could have made a difference. I know a lot of people my age are dealing with similar things, and I wish there was more support out there for kids like me who aren't sure what they want to do next. Maybe that's something I want to work toward in the future, even if I don't know exactly how yet.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Cynthia Williams: Right now, I don't have a partner or any children. My family is still my main support system — my parents and my two younger siblings. My oldest brother is in the military, and he's been away for a few years now, but we talk often on the phone. My sister is in college, and she's the one who encouraged me to think about going back to school eventually. My parents are still living in the same house we grew up in, and even though they're getting older, they're doing okay. I visit them as much as I can, especially on weekends. I don't see myself getting married anytime soon, and I'm not sure if I want kids, but I know my family will always be there for me. They've been through a lot, and I want to make sure I'm there for them too, even if my life takes me in a different direction.

Going through those interview questions made me reflect on how far I've come and how much my family has shaped who I am. Talking about my childhood reminded me of the love and support I've always had, even when things were tough. It also made me realize how much I've grown since that uncertain time after high school. Choosing to take a gap year wasn't a dramatic moment, but it was a quiet decision that helped me find my footing. I wish I had reached out for more help back then, but I'm grateful for the lessons I learned on my own. And even now, knowing my family is still there for me gives me strength to keep moving forward, even if I don't have all the answers yet.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Cynthia Williams: My younger brother, Marcus, is still at home, and he's always been the more outgoing one of us. He's got a real talent for fixing things — cars, electronics, you name it. I remember when he was in high school, he used to tinker with old radios and fix them up just for fun. He's the one who got me into music, actually. He introduced me to a lot of different genres, and that's how I got into playing the guitar. We don't talk as much as we used to, mostly because he's so busy with work and his own life, but I still care about him a lot. He's always been there for me, even when I wasn't sure what I wanted. I think he's the reason I never gave up on trying to figure things out — he showed me that it's okay to take your time and find your own path.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Cynthia Williams: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been important to me over the years. One of them is Aisha, who I met in high school. She was one of the few people who really understood me, even when I was quiet and reserved. We used to hang out at the library or just sit on the steps of the school and talk about music, books, and our dreams. She was the one who encouraged me to try writing, and she still reads my stuff whenever I send it her way. She's in nursing school now, and though we don't see each other as much as we used to, I know I can always count on her. Then there's my coworker, Jamal, who works at the bookstore with me. He's been a good friend and a sounding board for me, especially during the time I was trying to figure out what to do after high school. He's the one who first suggested taking a gap year, and I'm grateful for that. I don't have a huge social circle, but the people I do have in my life — my friends, my family, even my coworkers — they've all played a part in shaping who I am today.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Cynthia Williams: I live in a neighborhood that's pretty much the same as the one I grew up in — still in Columbia, still on Martin Luther King Jr Blvd, just a few blocks away from where I used to walk to school. It's a mix of old and new — some of the houses are decades old, with peeling paint and front porches where neighbors used to sit and chat, but there are also newer apartment buildings going up, especially near the downtown area. The streets aren't always the safest, especially at night, but there's a real sense of community here. People know each other, and if you're in trouble, someone will usually look out for you. The local park is a big part of the neighborhood — it's where kids play, where people walk their dogs, and where I used to sit and read when I was younger. I like that it's not too far from everything — the bookstore where I work, the community center where I used to go for free classes, and even the bus stop that takes me to the college if I decide to go back. It's not glamorous, but it's home, and I feel like I belong here, even if I'm still figuring out what that means for my future.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Cynthia Williams: I would say I feel mostly safe here, but there are definitely times when I'm more cautious, especially after dark. I've seen some things over the years — petty theft, occasional fights — but nothing that's ever made me feel truly unsafe. The neighborhood has its challenges, but it's also where I've always felt connected to people. I know most of my neighbors by name, and they know me too. If I'm out walking or coming home late from work, I always keep my phone close and take the well-lit route. It's not perfect, but I think the sense of community here helps keep things from getting worse. I don't want to sound like I'm ignoring the problems, but I also don't want to lose the sense of belonging that this place gives me.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Cynthia Williams: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. The good thing is, I know this place inside and out. I know which streets are quieter, which stores are friendly, and which corners to avoid if I'm out late. There's a rhythm to life here that I've grown used to — the sound of kids laughing in the park, the smell of barbecue from the corner shop, the way the sun sets over the old church on the hill. But it's not all easy. Sometimes I feel like I'm stuck in a cycle, working the same job, going to the same places, not sure if I'm making progress or just staying in one place. I guess that's part of what makes me want to go back to school someday. I want to break out of that cycle, not just for myself, but for my family too. They've always supported me, but I want to be the one who can support them, not the other way around. It's not about leaving this place — it's about finding a way to grow here, even if it takes time.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood made me realize how much my roots still shape me, even as I try to figure out my future. Talking about my family reminded me of how much they've always been there for me, even when I wasn't sure what I wanted. It also made me think about how much I want to be there for them, not just as a daughter or sister, but as someone who can support them in return. When I talked about my neighborhood, I felt a mix of pride and frustration — proud of the sense of community and the way people look out for each other, but frustrated by the feeling of being stuck in a cycle I want to break. I know I can't change everything overnight, but I'm starting to believe that small steps, like going back to school, can make a difference. I'm still figuring it all out, but I'm grateful for the people and places that have helped me get this far.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Cynthia Williams: A typical week for me is pretty consistent, though there are a few variations depending on my schedule. I work part-time at the bookstore, usually from Wednesday to Sunday, so my days tend to start later on those days. On weekdays, I wake up around 7 or 8, have a quick breakfast, and then head to work. After work, I like to go for a walk in the park or sit on my porch and read — it's my way of unwinding. I also try to spend time with my family, especially on weekends. My mom usually cooks something special, and we sit down for dinner together. On some nights, I'll go out with Aisha or Jamal, but those are more of a treat than a regular thing. I also have a few days a week where I study or look into classes at the community college, even if I haven't officially enrolled yet. It's not much, but it's something. The rest of the time, I just try to stay grounded, keep my head down, and keep moving forward — one day at a time.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Cynthia Williams: I work part-time at a local bookstore called 'Page Turner's,' which is actually just a few blocks away from my house. I usually work Wednesday through Sunday, from around 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., which gives me the rest of the day to take care of myself and my family. The job isn't glamorous — I spend a lot of time shelving books, helping customers find what they're looking for, and occasionally doing light cleaning — but I enjoy it. There's something comforting about being surrounded by books, even if I don't have a lot of time to read these days. My coworkers are pretty laid-back, and Jamal, who I mentioned earlier, is one of the managers. He's been a good mentor to me, even if he doesn't always realize it. I've also started helping out with some weekend events at the bookstore, like author signings or poetry nights, which is something I never thought I'd do. It's a small step, but it's given me a little more confidence in myself — and maybe even a little more direction.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Cynthia Williams: Outside of work and family time, I also have a few small routines that help me stay grounded. Every morning, before I leave the house, I take a few minutes to sit on the porch and just breathe — it's my way of starting the day with some calm. I also try to keep a journal, even if I only write in it a few times a week. It's not about being poetic or anything, just jotting down thoughts, things I'm grateful for, or even things that are on my mind. It helps me process stuff, especially when I'm feeling stuck or unsure. I also have this little habit of listening to music while I work — mostly old soul or jazz. It reminds me of my brother, Marcus, and how he always used to play music around the house. I think it's one of the few ways I can feel connected to who I was growing up, even if I'm not exactly sure who I'm becoming now.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Cynthia Williams: One of the recent changes to my daily routine has been starting to take online classes from the community college. I've been enrolled in a few courses on weekends, mostly introductory ones in English and social sciences. It's been a bit of a challenge balancing work, family, and school, but I'm trying to make it work. I've also started going to the community center more often — they have free workshops on things like resume writing and financial literacy, and I think it's important to take advantage of those resources. I used to feel like I wasn't ready for anything serious, but now I'm starting to see that small steps really do add up. It's not always easy, but I'm trying to be more proactive about my future — for myself, and for my family too.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Cynthia Williams: I don't have children of my own yet, but I've spent a lot of time thinking about what it would be like to raise them in a place like this. If I did have kids, I'd want them to grow up with the same sense of community I had — knowing their neighbors, feeling safe in their own neighborhood, and having access to opportunities that help them build a better future. I imagine their days would start with school, maybe walking to the same park where I used to sit and read. After school, they might join a community program or take part in something like the after-school tutoring that I used to see at the community center. I'd want them to have the chance to explore their interests, whether it's music, writing, or something else, and I'd do everything I can to support them, just like my parents did for me.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by the people and places I've known all along. Talking about my family reminded me of how deeply they've influenced me, not just through their support, but through the values they've passed down — like the importance of learning, even when things aren't easy. It also made me think about how I want to be there for them, not just as a daughter or sister, but as someone who can support them in return. When I talked about my neighborhood, I felt a mix of pride and frustration — proud of the sense of community and the way people look out for each other, but frustrated by the feeling of being stuck in a cycle I want to break. I know I can't change everything overnight, but I'm starting to believe that small steps, like going back to school, can make a difference. I'm still figuring it all out, but I'm grateful for the people and places that have helped me get this far. My daily routines, from my job at the bookstore to my quiet moments on the porch, are all part of the rhythm I've built for myself — and while I may not have everything figured out, I'm trying to move forward, one step at a time.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Cynthia Williams: As for my health, I'd say I'm generally in pretty good shape, though I don't always take the best care of myself. I try to eat healthy when I can, but with my budget and work schedule, it's not always easy. I usually stick to simple meals — maybe some grilled chicken, rice, and vegetables — but I know I could be doing better. I don't get sick too often, but I do have this habit of pushing through when I'm tired or not feeling well. I remember one time, a few years back, when I got really bad allergies and didn't take the time to see a doctor. I just kept working through it, thinking I'd get better on my own. In hindsight, that wasn't the smartest move. I've started going to the clinic more regularly now, especially since I'm thinking about going back to school. I know I need to take care of myself if I want to make it through the next steps in my life. I also try to stay active — I walk a lot, especially in the park, and I've been thinking about joining a fitness class at the community center. It's just one more thing to add to my plate, but I think it's important. Health isn't something I used to think about much, but lately, I've been realizing how much it affects everything else in my life.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Cynthia Williams: What makes it easy to stay healthy is knowing that even small things, like walking in the park or eating a balanced meal, can make a difference. I find that when I'm out in the neighborhood, surrounded by familiar faces and the rhythm of everyday life, I feel more motivated to take care of myself. But what makes it hard is the constant balancing act between work, family, and trying to move forward with my education. Sometimes, when I'm stretched thin, I forget to prioritize my health — like skipping a meal to save money or pushing through fatigue because I don't want to slow down. I know I need to be better about it, not just for myself, but because I want to be there for my family and for whatever future I'm trying to build. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that taking care of my body is just as important as taking care of my mind.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Cynthia Williams: In the past two years, there wasn't anything major that happened with my health — nothing like a broken bone or a serious diagnosis. But there were a few things that stood out. I remember a few months ago, I started having some back pain, probably from sitting too long at work or carrying heavy boxes at the bookstore. At first, I just ignored it, thinking it would go away on its own. But then it started getting worse, especially after long days. I finally went to the clinic, and the doctor said it was probably from poor posture and muscle strain. He gave me some exercises and told me to take it easy for a while. That was a wake-up call for me — I realized I hadn't been taking care of my body like I should have. I started stretching more, and I even bought a small foam roller to use at home. It's been helping, but I know I still have a long way to go. I guess the point is, I'm learning that health isn't just about not being sick — it's about taking care of yourself every day, even in the little ways.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Cynthia Williams: Honestly, I haven't had anything that严重 enough to really stop me from working or taking care of my family, but I know it could have been worse. The back pain I mentioned earlier was a reminder that even small things can add up and affect your ability to keep going. I remember one day, after a long shift at the bookstore, I was helping my mom with some errands and I felt this sharp pain in my lower back. I had to stop and sit down for a while, and that was the first time I realized how much I was pushing myself without really thinking about it. I don't want to be in a position where I can't support my family or myself because I ignored my body's signals. That's why I've been trying to make small changes — like taking more breaks at work, stretching more, and even looking into some physical therapy classes at the community center. I know it's not a quick fix, but I'm learning that taking care of myself isn't just about being healthy — it's about being there for the people I love and the future I want to build.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Cynthia Williams: Over the past year, I've been feeling a mix of things — mostly steady, but with a lot of quiet uncertainty. There's been a sense of progress, like when I started taking those online classes and going to the community center more often. It feels like I'm finally doing something to move forward, even if it's not as fast as I'd like. But there are also days when I feel stuck, like I'm just going through the motions, working the same job, walking the same streets, and not really changing anything. I think part of it is the weight of knowing I want more for myself and my family, but not knowing exactly how to get there. I've been trying to be more patient with myself, though. I used to think I had to have everything figured out before I could take a step, but now I'm realizing that it's okay to take small steps and not know where they'll lead. I'm still learning, still growing, and I think that's what matters most — not how fast I'm moving, but that I'm moving at all.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me think a lot about how my life has been shaped by the small, everyday choices I make — like going back to school, taking care of my health, and trying to balance work, family, and my future. It also made me realize how much I've been holding back, not because I didn't want to grow, but because I didn't know how to start. Talking about my health reminded me that I can't keep pushing through without taking care of myself, and that's something I need to be more mindful of moving forward. It's not always easy to take those first steps, but I'm starting to see that they matter — even if they're not always big or dramatic.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Cynthia Williams: I think I've struggled with anxiety more than anything else, though I didn't always recognize it for what it was. There were times when I felt like I was carrying the weight of everything — my family's expectations, my own uncertainty about the future, and the pressure to do something with my life. I used to feel like I was always on the edge of something, like I was waiting for the right moment to make a move, but I never knew when that moment would come. I remember lying awake at night, thinking about all the possibilities and all the things I wasn't sure about. It wasn't a constant feeling, but it was there enough to make me feel stuck in my own head. I didn't talk about it much, not even with Aisha or Jamal, because I didn't want to seem like I was giving up or not trying hard enough. But looking back, I think that anxiety was just another part of the journey — something I had to learn how to live with, not necessarily something I had to get rid of. I'm still learning how to manage it, but I'm starting to see that it doesn't define me. It's just one part of who I am, and I'm trying to be kinder to myself when it shows up.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Cynthia Williams: For my family, it's been a mix of support and quiet worry, I think. My parents have always been there for me, but I can see the way they look at me sometimes — like they're proud of me for trying, but also worried that I'm not moving fast enough. My mom especially, she's the one who always says, 'You're doing the best you can, and that's all anyone can ask for.' But I know she wants more for me, just like she wanted more for my brother and sister. My dad, he's more laid-back about it, but I can tell he's been watching me closely, waiting to see if I'm going to take that next step. As for my siblings, my sister is the one who's been the most encouraging — she's in college now, and she keeps reminding me that it's never too late to start something new. My brother, Marcus, he's been busy with work and his own life, but I know he's proud of me in his own way. He always says I'm more like him than I think, and that means a lot. I think what's been hardest for my family is seeing me struggle with uncertainty — not because they don't believe in me, but because they know how much it means to me to find my own way. And I think that's why they keep supporting me, even when I don't have all the answers yet.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Cynthia Williams: For me, religion or spirituality hasn't really played a big role in my life — not in the way it does for some people. I grew up in a household where my parents didn't really practice any specific faith, and I never really felt the need to fill that space with something else. I think I've always been more of a person who looks for meaning in the everyday — in the way the sun sets over the old church on the hill, or in the quiet moments I have on my porch with a book. I know some people find comfort in prayer or going to church, and I respect that. But for me, it's more about the people I love, the community I'm part of, and the small steps I take every day to build a better life. I don't think of it as spirituality in the traditional sense, but I do believe in something bigger than myself — maybe not a god, but the idea that we all have a role to play in making things better for each other. That's what keeps me going, even when I don't have all the answers.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Cynthia Williams: Honestly, I don't use social media much — not the way a lot of people do. I have a Facebook account, mostly to stay in touch with family and old friends, but I don't spend a lot of time on it. I've seen how it can take over people's lives, and I don't want that for myself. I remember when I was in high school, I used to scroll through Instagram and feel like everyone else was doing something more exciting or important than me. It made me feel even more stuck in my own head. Now, I try to limit my time online, especially when I'm feeling unsure about things. I do follow a few pages that post about books or music — stuff that reminds me of what I love — but I don't get sucked into the comparisons or the noise. I think it's easier for me to stay grounded when I'm not constantly looking at other people's lives. I know that's not the case for everyone, but for me, it's just one more thing I don't need to complicate my life with.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Cynthia Williams: Honestly, I don't think I've ever really relied on social media for support — not emotional or financial. I know a lot of people use it to vent or ask for help, but I've always found it easier to talk to someone in person, even if it's just my mom or Aisha. I guess I feel like the internet can be a good place to connect, but it's also full of noise and distractions. I've seen people post about their struggles and get support from strangers, and I respect that. But for me, I've always preferred the quiet support of the people I know — the ones who've been there through the good times and the tough ones. I don't think I'd ever ask for help online, not because I don't need it, but because I've always believed that the people I care about are the ones who will be there for me, even if I don't say it out loud.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect on how much my health and mental well-being have shaped my journey over the past year. Talking about my back pain was a reminder that even small physical issues can have a big impact on how I feel about myself and my ability to move forward. It also made me realize how much I've been pushing through without really taking care of myself — not just physically, but emotionally too. When I talked about anxiety, I felt like I was finally giving voice to something I've been carrying in silence for a long time. It's not easy to admit that I've struggled with feeling stuck or uncertain, but it's also a step toward understanding myself better. I think the most important thing I took away from those questions is that it's okay to not have everything figured out, and it's okay to ask for help when I need it — whether it's from a doctor, a friend, or even just from myself. I'm still learning how to balance everything, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself in the process.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Cynthia Williams: Over the past few months, I've noticed my stress levels have gone up a bit, mostly because I'm juggling more things than ever before — work, school, and trying to figure out my future. It's not that I'm overwhelmed, exactly, but there are days when I feel like I'm just going through the motions, trying to keep everything moving forward without really knowing where I'm headed. I've been trying to cope by sticking to the things that ground me — like my morning walks in the park, writing in my journal, and even just sitting on my porch and listening to music. I've also started talking to Aisha more about how I'm feeling, which has helped a lot. It's strange, but sometimes just saying things out loud makes them feel less heavy. I'm still learning how to manage my emotions, but I think the most important thing is that I'm not ignoring them anymore. I'm trying to be kinder to myself, even when I don't have all the answers — and I think that's a step in the right direction.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Cynthia Williams: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and transportation. Rent is the biggest chunk of my budget — I live in a small apartment above my aunt's garage, and it's not much, but it's enough to keep a roof over my head. Groceries are another thing — I try to buy in bulk when I can, but with my part-time job and the cost of living here, it's still tight. I also have to pay for the bus pass to get to work and to the community college when I'm taking classes. I know it's not a lot, but it adds up. My parents still help out when they can, especially with things like utilities or unexpected bills, but I don't want to rely on them too much. I've been trying to save a little bit each month, even if it's just a few dollars, just in case something comes up. It's not easy, but I'm learning that even small steps can make a difference — like cooking more meals at home instead of eating out, or walking more instead of taking the bus when I can. It's all about finding ways to stretch what I have and still keep moving forward.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Cynthia Williams: Honestly, it's hard to say exactly how much we spent last month because I don't track everything in detail — I'm more of a 'keep it simple' kind of person. But I know rent was definitely the biggest part of it, maybe around $600 or so. Groceries probably came in close behind, maybe around $300, depending on what we needed. Then there's the bus pass, utilities, and a few small things like toiletries or phone bills. I think the total was somewhere around $1,200 to $1,300, give or take. That's not unusual for us — it's pretty much what we spend every month. The thing is, it's not always the same. Sometimes we have to cut back on groceries if one of us is working extra hours or if there's an unexpected bill. Other times, we might spend a little more on something like a new pair of shoes or a special dinner out. But for the most part, we stick to what we can afford, and we make it work. I know it's not a lot, but it's enough to keep us going — and that's what matters most.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Cynthia Williams: We rent our home — it's a small apartment above my aunt's garage, just a few blocks from where I grew up. It's not much, but it's convenient and affordable. My aunt lets me stay there for a reduced rate, and in return, I help her out with some chores around the house, like mowing the lawn or doing light cleaning. It's a good arrangement for both of us. I don't own anything big, like a car or even a lot of furniture, but I don't mind. I think it's better to have a place that's simple and functional rather than something fancy I can't afford. Plus, being close to home means I can visit my parents and siblings whenever I need to — which is important, especially when I'm feeling stuck or unsure about things. I know it's not the life everyone dreams of, but it's mine, and I'm trying to make the best of it.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Cynthia Williams: Over the past year, my bills have stayed pretty consistent, but there have been a few things that made them go up or down depending on the time of year. For example, during the winter months, our heating bill tends to be a bit higher, and we usually have to budget a little more for that. Then, around the holidays, we might spend a little more on groceries or small gifts for family, but it's nothing too extravagant. On the flip side, during the summer, we don't use as much electricity for heating, so that part of the bill goes down. I also noticed that when I started taking online classes, I had to pay for some additional fees or materials, which added a little bit to the monthly cost. But overall, I think we've been pretty good at managing our money — sticking to what we can afford and making sure we don't overspend. It's not always easy, especially when things come up unexpectedly, but I've learned that being careful with what I have is one of the best ways to keep moving forward.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me think a lot about how my family and my approach to social media have shaped my emotional well-being. Talking about my family reminded me of how much they've always been there for me, even when I wasn't sure what I wanted or how to move forward. Their support, even when it's quiet or filled with worry, is something I deeply appreciate. It also made me realize how much I want to be there for them in return — not just as a daughter or sister, but as someone who can support them in their own ways. When I talked about social media, it made me reflect on how I've chosen to stay away from it, not because I don't want to connect, but because I've seen how it can take over people's lives and make them feel worse about themselves. I think it's easier for me to stay grounded when I'm not constantly comparing myself to others or feeling like I need to present a certain image online. I've always preferred the quiet support of the people I know — the ones who've been there through the good times and the tough ones — and I think that's what keeps me moving forward, even when I don't have all the answers yet.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Cynthia Williams: I don't have a formal savings account, but I do save in small ways whenever I can. For example, I set aside a few dollars from my paycheck every week, even if it's just $10 or $15. I keep that money in a jar on my shelf, and I use it for things like unexpected expenses or when I need to buy something I can't afford right away. It's not much, but it gives me a sense of control over my money, even if I don't have a lot. I also try to be mindful of how I spend — like buying secondhand clothes or using coupons when I go to the grocery store. I know it's not the same as having a big savings account, but I think it's better than nothing. I want to save for something bigger someday, like going back to school full-time or even buying a car, but for now, I'm just trying to make sure I don't fall behind. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that even small habits can add up over time — and that's something I can be proud of.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Cynthia Williams: For me, saving has mostly been about preparing for the unexpected — like a sudden medical bill or a car repair I can't afford. I know I don't have a lot, but I try to be responsible with what I have. Last year, I started setting aside a little more money each month, just in case something comes up. I don't dream about buying a house or anything like that — not yet, anyway. But I do want to save enough to go back to school full-time without having to worry about money. I know it's a long way off, but I'm trying to take it one step at a time. It's not about having a lot, it's about being ready when the time comes — and for now, that's enough.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Cynthia Williams: My occupation right now is working part-time at 'Page Turner's,' the local bookstore where I've been for a few years now. The work isn't glamorous, but it's steady, and I've found a kind of comfort in it. My main duties are shelving books, helping customers find what they're looking for, and occasionally doing light cleaning or organizing events. I've also started helping out with some weekend events, like author signings or poetry nights, which is something I never thought I'd do. It's funny, really — I used to be the quiet kid who preferred books to people, and now I'm the one introducing people to new authors or helping them pick out the perfect gift. It's not the kind of job that changes the world, but it gives me a sense of purpose, and I think that matters more than I used to believe. I don't know if I'll stay in this line of work forever, but for now, it's something I can rely on — and that's not nothing.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Cynthia Williams: I usually work around 20 to 25 hours a week, depending on the season and whether there are any special events at the bookstore. During busier times, like the holidays or when we have author signings or poetry nights, I might pick up a few extra hours to help out. But most of the time, it's a steady schedule — Wednesday through Sunday, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. It gives me enough time to take care of myself, visit my family, and still have some space to think about what I want to do next. I know it's not a lot, but it's enough to keep me going — and honestly, I think that's what matters most right now.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Cynthia Williams: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. I've always focused on keeping things simple — one job, one place, one life that I can manage without feeling stretched too thin. I know some people take on multiple jobs to make ends meet, and I respect that, but for me, it's been about finding balance. I work at the bookstore, I take care of my family when I can, and I try to make time for myself — even if it's just sitting on my porch with a book or walking through the park. I don't know if I could handle more than that right now. There's something about having too many responsibilities at once that makes me feel like I'm losing myself, and I don't want that. I think it's better to be steady, even if it's not fast — and for now, that's what I need.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how my emotional well-being and financial situation are deeply connected. Talking about my stress and coping strategies reminded me that even small things — like walking in the park, writing in my journal, or just sitting on my porch — can make a big difference in how I feel. It also made me realize how much I rely on the people I love, especially Aisha and my family, to help me through tough moments. When I talked about my budget and how we manage our money, I felt a mix of pride and frustration — proud of how we make it work, but frustrated by the limitations that come with not having much. I know I can't change everything overnight, but I'm learning that even small steps — like saving a little each week or cutting back on unnecessary expenses — can help build a better future. It's not always easy to balance everything, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself and more patient with the process. I'm still figuring it out, but I'm grateful for the people and the small things that keep me moving forward.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Cynthia Williams: In total, my household makes around $1,500 to $1,600 a month, depending on how much I earn from the bookstore and whether my parents are able to help out with anything. My paycheck is pretty steady — I make about $12 an hour, and with the hours I work, that adds up to roughly $1,200 a month. My parents still help out with some of the bills, especially when things get tight, but I try not to rely on them too much. I know it's not a lot, but it's enough to keep us going — and honestly, I think that's what matters most right now. It's not about having everything, it's about making the most of what we have and keeping our heads above water.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Cynthia Williams: I've been working at 'Page Turner's' for almost three years now, and while it's not the most glamorous job, it's been a steady part of my life. The benefits aren't anything fancy — there's no health insurance or paid vacation, just the basics like sick days when I really need them. But what I appreciate most is the flexibility. I can work the hours that fit around my family and my studies, and the manager, Jamal, is pretty understanding when I need to take a break or adjust my schedule. The coworkers are friendly, and even though we don't make a lot of money, there's a real sense of community in the store. We all know each other's names, we share music and stories, and sometimes we even help each other out with things like transportation or groceries. It's not much, but it's enough to make me feel like I belong — and that, I think, is one of the most important things about any job.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Cynthia Williams: My relationships at work are pretty good, all things considered. Jamal, my manager, is someone I really respect — he's been there for me since I started, and even though he doesn't always realize it, he's been a mentor in his own way. He's not the kind of person who yells or gives strict orders; he's more like the guy who knows when to give you space and when to push you a little. I think that's why I've stayed at the bookstore for so long — it's not just about the job, it's about the people. As for my coworkers, we're all pretty laid-back, and we've built this kind of unspoken understanding. We know when to help each other out, whether it's covering a shift or just lending an ear when someone's having a rough day. I don't think any of us make a lot of money, but we all have our own reasons for being there, and I think that shared sense of purpose makes the place feel like home in its own way.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Cynthia Williams: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's still a bit of flexibility depending on the week. I usually work Wednesday through Sunday, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., and that's been my rhythm for a while now. But if there's a special event, like a poetry night or an author signing, Jamal might ask me to stay a little later or come in on a Monday if things get busy. I also have some say in how I manage my hours — if I need to leave early for a family commitment or if I'm feeling under the weather, Jamal is usually okay with adjusting my shift as long as I cover it with someone else. It's not perfect, but I think that flexibility is one of the things that keeps me from feeling like I'm stuck in a routine. I can plan my days around my studies, my family, and even my walks in the park. It's not much, but it gives me a sense of control over my time — and that's something I really value.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Cynthia Williams: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is manageable, but it's not without its challenges. I know I don't have a lot, but I also know that I'm not alone in this — my family has always been there to help when things get tight, and I try to be there for them in return. I don't see myself as someone who's struggling, but I also don't see myself as someone who's completely secure. It's this in-between place, where I'm trying to build something better without having all the tools or resources I wish I had. I think the hardest part is knowing that I want more for myself and for my family, but not knowing exactly how to get there. It's not about being rich or having everything figured out — it's about being able to take care of the basics, to have a place to live, to eat, to work, and to keep moving forward. I know it's not easy, but I'm learning that even small steps — like saving a little each week or taking online classes — can make a difference. I don't have all the answers, but I'm trying to be patient with myself and with the process. For now, that's enough.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how my financial situation and work life are deeply connected to my sense of stability and purpose. Talking about how my bills fluctuate throughout the year reminded me of the small but consistent efforts I make to manage our household — like budgeting for heating in the winter or cutting back on expenses when needed. It also made me realize how much I rely on the support of my family, even when I try not to depend on them too much. When I talked about my job at the bookstore, I felt a mix of pride and gratitude — proud of the steady work I have, and grateful for the flexibility and community it offers. I think what struck me most was how much my life is built on small, manageable steps — not just in my finances, but in everything else too. I don't have a lot, but I'm learning that it's enough to keep moving forward, one day at a time.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Cynthia Williams: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My dad worked at a local factory, and my mom was a part-time clerk at a grocery store. They didn't have a lot of money, but they always made sure we had food on the table and a roof over our heads. I remember seeing my mom work long hours, sometimes coming home tired but always smiling when she saw us. My dad would come home from the factory, and even though he was exhausted, he'd sit down with us for dinner and talk about his day. They didn't have a lot, but they gave us everything they could. I think that's why I always felt like I had to work hard — not just for myself, but for them too. I don't know if they ever thought about their own dreams, but they always made sure we had a chance to have ours. That's something I'll never forget.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Cynthia Williams: My mom worked as a part-time clerk at a grocery store, and her job was pretty much the same every day — scanning items, restocking shelves, and helping customers find what they needed. She didn't have a lot of time for herself, but she always made sure we had what we needed. I remember her coming home with her hands sore from lifting heavy boxes, but she'd still sit down and talk to us about her day. My dad worked at a local factory, assembling parts for machines. It was a tough job — long hours, repetitive work, and not much in the way of benefits — but he never complained. He always said that as long as he could provide for us, it was worth it. Looking back, I think their jobs were more than just a way to make money — they were a way to show us what hard work looked like. They didn't have a lot, but they gave us everything they could, and that's something I carry with me every day.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Cynthia Williams: My mom worked at a local grocery store called 'Fresh Start Market,' and it was one of those places where everyone knew each other — customers, cashiers, and even the people who restocked the shelves. It was a small, family-owned business, and though it wasn't much, it felt like a real community hub. My dad worked at a factory owned by a company called 'South Carolina Manufacturing,' which made parts for industrial machines. It was a pretty rough place — loud, hot, and not much in the way of safety equipment — but he always said it was a good job because it paid the bills. I remember seeing him come home with calluses on his hands and a tired look in his eyes, but he'd always smile when he saw us. I think what I learned from both of them was that work isn't always about the money — it's about showing up, doing your part, and making sure the people you love have what they need. That's something I've carried with me, even as I try to figure out my own path.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Cynthia Williams: A few years from now, I hope I'm still in Columbia, but maybe with a little more stability — not just for myself, but for my family too. I hope I'm back in school full-time, working toward a degree in something like English or social work, because I want to be able to help people the way my parents helped me. I don't know exactly what that will look like yet — whether I'll be living in the same neighborhood or somewhere else, whether I'll have a partner or not — but I hope I'm still grounded in the things that matter: my family, my community, and the small but meaningful steps I take every day. I hope I'm not still stuck in the same cycle of working the same job and not moving forward, but I also hope I'm not rushing into something just because I think I should. I want to be someone who can support my family, not just depend on them, and I want to be someone who can look back and know I did the best I could with what I had. I don't know if that's a lot to hope for, but it's what I keep trying to work toward — one step at a time.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Cynthia Williams: What I value the most in my life is the people — my family, my friends, the neighbors who've been there for me through thick and thin. I think it's easy to get caught up in wanting more, wanting to be somewhere else or do something bigger, but what keeps me grounded is knowing I have people who care about me, even when I don't have all the answers. I value the quiet moments too — like sitting on my porch with a book, walking through the park, or just listening to music and thinking. Those things remind me that I don't have to rush through life to be living it. I also value the idea of growth, not just for myself, but for the people I love. I want to be someone who can support my family, not just depend on them, and I want to be someone who can look back and know I did the best I could with what I had. It's not about being perfect — it's about showing up, even when it's hard, and trying to make things better, one small step at a time.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me think a lot about how my work and financial situation shape my daily life and my sense of stability. Talking about my income and how my household manages money reminded me of the small but consistent efforts I make to keep things going — like budgeting, saving a little each week, and relying on the support of my family when needed. It also made me realize how much I value the flexibility and community at my job at the bookstore, even though it's not a high-paying or glamorous position. I think what struck me most was how much my work life is tied to my ability to plan for the future, whether it's through taking online classes or trying to save for something bigger. It's not about having everything figured out, but about finding ways to move forward, even if it's one step at a time.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been like looking back at the pieces of my life and seeing how they all fit together, even if the picture isn't always clear. It reminded me of how much I've grown — not just in the big ways, like deciding to go back to school or taking care of my health, but in the small, quiet moments too, like sitting on my porch with a book or walking through the park with my thoughts. I've always felt like I was moving forward, even if it wasn't always fast or dramatic. This process made me realize how much my family, my neighborhood, and the people I love have shaped who I am, even when I didn't always see it. It also made me think about how much I still have to learn — about myself, about my future, and about the things I want to build for my family. I don't have all the answers yet, and I probably never will, but I'm learning that it's okay to keep moving forward, one step at a time, even when the path isn't clear.
